speaker: CLAUDIUS
text_entry: ACT V

speaker: CLAUDIUS
text_entry: SCENE I. The plains of Philippi.

speaker: CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Enter OCTAVIUS, ANTONY, and their army

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Now, Antony, our hopes are answered:

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: You said the enemy would not come down,

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: But keep the hills and upper regions;

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: It proves not so: their battles are at hand;

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: They mean to warn us at Philippi here,

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Answering before we do demand of them.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Tut, I am in their bosoms, and I know

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Wherefore they do it: they could be content

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: To visit other places; and come down

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: With fearful bravery, thinking by this face

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: To fasten in our thoughts that they have courage;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: But 'tis not so.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Prepare you, generals:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The enemy comes on in gallant show;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Their bloody sign of battle is hung out,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And something to be done immediately.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Octavius, lead your battle softly on,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Upon the left hand of the even field.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Upon the right hand I; keep thou the left.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Why do you cross me in this exigent?

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: I do not cross you; but I will do so.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: March

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Drum. Enter BRUTUS, CASSIUS, and their Army; LUCILIUS, TITINIUS, MESSALA, and others

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: They stand, and would have parley.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Stand fast, Titinius: we must out and talk.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Mark Antony, shall we give sign of battle?

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: No, Caesar, we will answer on their charge.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Make forth; the generals would have some words.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Stir not until the signal.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Words before blows: is it so, countrymen?

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Not that we love words better, as you do.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Good words are better than bad strokes, Octavius.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: In your bad strokes, Brutus, you give good words:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Witness the hole you made in Caesar's heart,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Crying 'Long live! hail, Caesar!'

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Antony,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: The posture of your blows are yet unknown;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But for your words, they rob the Hybla bees,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And leave them honeyless.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Not stingless too.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: O, yes, and soundless too;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For you have stol'n their buzzing, Antony,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And very wisely threat before you sting.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Villains, you did not so, when your vile daggers

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Hack'd one another in the sides of Caesar:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: You show'd your teeth like apes, and fawn'd like hounds,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And bow'd like bondmen, kissing Caesar's feet;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Whilst damned Casca, like a cur, behind

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Struck Caesar on the neck. O you flatterers!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Flatterers! Now, Brutus, thank yourself:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: This tongue had not offended so to-day,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: If Cassius might have ruled.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Come, come, the cause: if arguing make us sweat,

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: The proof of it will turn to redder drops. Look;

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: I draw a sword against conspirators;

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: When think you that the sword goes up again?

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Never, till Caesar's three and thirty wounds

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Be well avenged; or till another Caesar

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Have added slaughter to the sword of traitors.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Caesar, thou canst not die by traitors' hands,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Unless thou bring'st them with thee.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: So I hope;

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: I was not born to die on Brutus' sword.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: O, if thou wert the noblest of thy strain,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Young man, thou couldst not die more honourable.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: A peevish schoolboy, worthless of such honour,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Join'd with a masker and a reveller!

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Old Cassius still!

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Come, Antony, away!

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Defiance, traitors, hurl we in your teeth:

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: If you dare fight to-day, come to the field;

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: If not, when you have stomachs.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Exeunt OCTAVIUS, ANTONY, and their army

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Why, now, blow wind, swell billow and swim bark!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: The storm is up, and all is on the hazard.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Ho, Lucilius! hark, a word with you.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: [Standing forth] My lord?

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: BRUTUS and LUCILIUS converse apart

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Messala!

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: [Standing forth]  What says my general?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Messala,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: This is my birth-day; as this very day

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Was Cassius born. Give me thy hand, Messala:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Be thou my witness that against my will,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: As Pompey was, am I compell'd to set

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Upon one battle all our liberties.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: You know that I held Epicurus strong

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And his opinion: now I change my mind,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And partly credit things that do presage.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Coming from Sardis, on our former ensign

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Two mighty eagles fell, and there they perch'd,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Gorging and feeding from our soldiers' hands;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Who to Philippi here consorted us:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: This morning are they fled away and gone;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And in their steads do ravens, crows and kites,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Fly o'er our heads and downward look on us,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: As we were sickly prey: their shadows seem

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: A canopy most fatal, under which

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Our army lies, ready to give up the ghost.

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Believe not so.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I but believe it partly;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: For I am fresh of spirit and resolved

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To meet all perils very constantly.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Even so, Lucilius.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Now, most noble Brutus,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: The gods to-day stand friendly, that we may,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Lovers in peace, lead on our days to age!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But since the affairs of men rest still incertain,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Let's reason with the worst that may befall.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: If we do lose this battle, then is this

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: The very last time we shall speak together:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: What are you then determined to do?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Even by the rule of that philosophy

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: By which I did blame Cato for the death

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Which he did give himself, I know not how,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: But I do find it cowardly and vile,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For fear of what might fall, so to prevent

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The time of life: arming myself with patience

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To stay the providence of some high powers

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That govern us below.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Then, if we lose this battle,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: You are contented to be led in triumph

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Thorough the streets of Rome?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: No, Cassius, no: think not, thou noble Roman,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That ever Brutus will go bound to Rome;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He bears too great a mind. But this same day

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Must end that work the ides of March begun;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And whether we shall meet again I know not.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Therefore our everlasting farewell take:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For ever, and for ever, farewell, Cassius!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: If we do meet again, why, we shall smile;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: If not, why then, this parting was well made.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: For ever, and for ever, farewell, Brutus!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: If we do meet again, we'll smile indeed;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: If not, 'tis true this parting was well made.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Why, then, lead on. O, that a man might know

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The end of this day's business ere it come!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: But it sufficeth that the day will end,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And then the end is known. Come, ho! away!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exeunt
